DOCNAME: CASE OF NILSEN AND JOHNSEN v. NORWAY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , Mr PERSON , and the second applicant , PERSON PERSON , are NORP citizens born in DATE and DATE and living in GPE . The first applicant is a police inspector , who at the material time was Chairman of ORG ( Norsk Politiforbund ) . The second applicant is a police constable and was at the relevant time Chairman of ORG ( PERSON ) , a branch of the former association . At the material time they were both working in the GPE police force .

CARDINAL . In DATE Mr PERSON , then a law student , and Mr ORG , then an associate professor of sociology at ORG , carried out an investigation into the phenomenon of violence in GPE , a city of CARDINAL inhabitants . They gathered material from the local hospital relating to all patients subjected to violence during DATE . Later , they included material from other sources . In DATE Mr Nordhus and PERSON published a summary of their previous reports in a book entitled GPE og dens ofre . En empirisk undersøkelse ( “ Violence and its ORG . An Empirical Study ” ) . The book extended to CARDINAL pages and included a DATE chapter on police brutality , which it defined as the unlawful use of physical force during the performance of police duties . The authors found , inter alia , that CARDINAL persons had been exposed to police brutality during the aforementioned period , CARDINAL of whom had been medically examined , and that the police in GPE were responsible for CARDINAL incidents a year of excessive and illegal use of force .

The book gave rise to a heated public debate . This involved in part researchers concerning the methods used and the scientific basis for the conclusions drawn , and in part members of the police and the prosecution .

CARDINAL . NORP In this connection ORG appointed a ORG ( utvalg ) of Inquiry consisting of Mr PERSON , professor of criminal and procedural law , and Mr PERSON , advocate before ORG . Their mandate was to verify whether the research of PERSON Nordhus and PERSON provided a basis for making any general observations as to the nature and extent of police brutality in GPE .

Assisted by a statistics expert and an expert on the use of interviews , the ORG interviewed QUANTITY persons , including QUANTITY police officers , CARDINAL public prosecutors , CARDINAL doctors who had taken blood samples at GPE police station , CARDINAL social workers who dealt especially with young criminals in GPE , CARDINAL defence lawyers with extensive experience of criminal cases in GPE , CARDINAL witnesses of police brutality and CARDINAL alleged victims of such misconduct . In a report published in DATE under the title Politivoldrapporten ( “ Report on Police Brutality ” ) PERSON and PERSON PERSON concluded :

“ Since ORG has been unable to reach a conclusion regarding individual accounts of situations , but has considered all the material as a whole ( see remarks on p. CARDINAL with reference to the recommendation of ORG ) , it will not , on the basis of the descriptions of the situations alone , be able to give any exact figure as to the number of incidents of police violence in GPE . However , on the basis of all the information concerning police violence in GPE received from various sources by ORG , it believes that the nature and the extent of police violence are far more serious than seems to be generally believed . On the strength of the evidence as a whole , the ORG assumes that the real extent hardly differs from the CARDINAL researchers’ estimates . However , the essential point must be that even the most cautious estimates that can be made on this basis indicate that the extent is alarming . ”

CARDINAL . The conclusions in the DATE report and its premises were called into question by ORG , amongst others . The association considered bringing defamation proceedings against Mr Bratholm , PERSON , Mr GPE and Mr PERSON but decided in DATE to refrain from such action .

CARDINAL . Newspapers in GPE , in particular , took a keen interest in the debate following publication of the DATE report . Prior to that , in DATE , the newspaper PERSON had stated that Mr PERSON had lied in connection with the collecting of material for his research . Mr Nordhus instituted defamation proceedings against the newspaper but in DATE ORG ( byrett ) dismissed the action on the ground that the accusation had been justified .

CARDINAL . PERSON continued his work on police brutality , eventually as an independent researcher . In DATE he published a book entitled PERSON ( “ Police Brutality ” ) , with the subtitle Omfang – årsak – forebyggelse . En studie i desinformasjon ( “ Extent – Causes – Prevention . A Study in Misinformation ” ) . He explained his use of the term “ misinformation ” as meaning the deliberate or negligent dissemination of incorrect information . It related to the “ false ” – or “ misunderstood ” – loyalty , leading police officers witnessing the excessive and unlawful use of force to keep quiet or cover the perpetrator by giving false testimony . Taking the DATE report as its point of departure the book provided additional facts , analyses and conclusions . It also contained strong criticism by PERSON of ORG judgment in the above - mentioned case brought by Mr GPE against PERSON .

CARDINAL . Following the publication of PERSON book Politivold the second applicant , as Chairman of ORG , was interviewed by the newspaper ORG . The interview was published in an article on CARDINAL DATE entitled ( all quotations below are translations from NORP ) “ PERSON out to get the police – An entire service has been denounced by anonymous persons ” and read :

“ ‘ The mood of officers in the police force has been swinging between despair and anger . An entire service has been denounced by anonymous persons . Many of the officers dread making an appearance in town because there is always someone to believe that there must be something in these allegations.’

This is what the Chairman of ORG , PERSON , told ORG . He describes Professor PERSON ’s recent report on police brutality in the GPE police force as ‘ pure misinformation intended to harm the police’ .
‘ Until the contrary has been proved , I would characterise this as a deliberate lie . The allegations come from anonymous sources and are clearly defamatory of the ORG
‘ Are you questioning PERSON motives for exposing police brutality?’
‘ There must be other ulterior motives . It appears as if the purpose has been to undermine confidence in the police.’
‘ Would you suggest that the information be investigated internally?’
‘ If there is any truth in it , we will do what we can to remedy the situation . Such a situation is not to our credit , and we are not interested in having such people in the force.’
‘ So you do not exclude the possibility that misconduct has occurred?’
‘ I discount the possibility that any officers have committed such outrages as described . But I can not exclude that some of them have in certain instances used force and gone too far.’ ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant , then Chairman of ORG , was quoted in an article published by the newspaper PERSON under the headline “ Unworthy of a law professor ” . The article read :

“ ‘ It is beneath the dignity of a law professor to present something like this . The allegations are completely frivolous since they are based on anonymous sources . They have nothing to do with reality.’
This was stated by PERSON , Chairman of ORG , in connection with the allegations made by Professor PERSON in his book on police brutality .

‘ I have spent my whole working life in the GPE police force , and can safely say that the allegations concerning police brutality bear no relation to reality . They are stories that would have been better suited to a DATE with space to fill than a socalled serious study’ , says PERSON .
Full parity

‘ I am puzzled by the motives behind such allegations,’ continues the Chairman of ORG . ‘ At any rate , it can not be in the interests of the rule of law and the public good to create such problems for an entire service . I would claim that the quality of the human resources within the police is fully on a par with that found among professors . We would not be able to base a charge against anyone on such flimsy grounds as Professor PERSON does . Then , at any rate , there would not be any rule of law in this country.’
Would not be tolerated
‘ But you are not denying that police brutality does occur?’
‘ Of course not , but that is a different question . Here it is a question of systematic use of violence and pure theft . Such conduct would not be tolerated within a police force.’

PERSON out that , although he has not studied the book closely , he considers that one can not leave what has emerged so far unchallenged . The problem is that it is difficult to contest the allegations because it is not an individual , but an entire service , which feels it has been libelled . He does , however , agree with Chief of Police , Mr Oscar Hordnes , who told PERSON DATE that there must be good reason for ORG ] to examine the matter more closely . ORG will also consider seeking a legal opinion on the book . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE Mr Bratholm and Mr Nordhus published a book – ORG av politivold og andre overgrep i GPE - politiet ( “ Documentation of police brutality and other misconduct in the GPE police force ” ) in which PERSON stated :

“ The harassment and persecution to which Mr DATE and in part Mr GPE – have been subjected in GPE are reminiscent of the fate of dissidents in east NORP countries . I doubt that there is anyone among us whose situation is closer to that of these dissidents than Mr GPE . It is almost a wonder that he has had the courage and strength to continue his struggle to bring the truth to light .

It is impossible to say how many officers in the GPE police force are involved in the unlawful practice described here ; hopefully only a small minority . It is , however , difficult to believe that a great many in the force could be unaware of the conduct of certain colleagues . But their silence is ensured by the pressing demand for ‘ PERSON . This has made it possible for the criminal sub - culture in the GPE police force – whose activities encompass various kinds of offences – to survive and most likely to flourish .

There is reason to believe that many of the actions against Mr Nordhus and PERSON are headed by somebody who is centrally placed DATE that there is somebody behind the scenes in the GPE police force who is pulling the strings , plotting strategies and laying plans together with a few highly trusted persons . According to information that has come to light , it may now be possible to identify the key people responsible for some of the misconduct . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE PERSON published a further book entitled Politiovergrep og personforfølgelse . CARDINAL forklaringer om politivold og andre overgrep i Bergenspolitiet ( “ Police misconduct and individual harassment . CARDINAL statements concerning police brutality and other forms of misconduct in the GPE police force ” ) , which to some extent was an update of PERSON and Mr PERSON ’s book of DATE . In the introduction PERSON stated :

“ Although abuse of power by the police does occur , and in some places far more frequently than in others , this does not mean that the majority of NORP police officers are guilty of such abuse . All the investigations indicate that a small minority of police officers have committed most of the incidents of abuse and are able to continue because the demands for ‘ PERSON are so strong within the police . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE the NORP law journal Lov og Rett published a special volume devoted to the issue of police violence . It included a number of articles by academics , amongst others by PERSON , criticising an investigation ordered by ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
PERSON also published a number of other articles on the subject of police brutality .

CARDINAL . After receiving from PERSON an unexpurgated version of the book published in DATE mentioning the informers’ names ( which until then had been known to the researchers only ) , the ORG ordered an investigation headed by ad hoc prosecutor Mr PERSON and police officers from another district .

In DATE the result of ORG investigation was made public : CARDINAL cases of alleged police brutality in GPE had been investigated . CARDINAL persons , including CARDINAL police officers , had been interviewed . Charges were brought against one police officer , who was subsequently acquitted . The overall conclusion reached in the investigation was essentially that the various allegations of police brutality were unfounded .

At the close of the investigation , CARDINAL of the interviewees were charged with having made false accusations against the police . QUANTITY of these persons were later convicted in jury trials before ORG ( lagmannsrett ) , which took place during the period from DATE and were referred to as the “ boomerang cases ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE a new statement by the first applicant was printed in NORP in GPE in an article carrying the following headlines :
“ Dramatic turn in the debate on brutality
ORG contacted
ORG is preparing legal action ”
The article read :

“ Not only has Professor PERSON now issued a demand that a government committee of inquiry should be set up to review what was long ago concluded by ORG , but ORG has now been reported to ORG for violating human rights ! A delegation from the international secretariat in GPE has already been in GPE . Their report is expected to be ready DATE .

‘ I have to admit that I was quite surprised when I was told about this recently . It seems as if gentlemen like Mr GPE , Mr PERSON and PERSON now realise that when one move does not work they try another’ , commented PERSON , Chairman of ORG .

In [ his ] view , the matter is about to get out of hand . He describes the reporting of the matter to ORG as an insult and feels that with the recent , sharp attacks by Professor PERSON and others , the limits of what can be called impartial research have long since been exceeded . ‘ In my view , one is faced with a form of skulduggery and private investigation where there is good reason to question the honesty of the GPE , PERSON said to ORG .

Just before the weekend Mr PERSON was in GPE , where he had talks with the newly appointed board of ORG ... PERSON says it was natural that the recent sharp attacks by Mr DATE , Mr PERSON and PERSON were one of the topics discussed .

‘ I intend to contact our lawyer ... DATE . He has DATE sent a letter to PERSON in which we demand an apology for the statements he has made . I think you can count on our instituting defamation proceedings in this matter . We can not put up with a situation where the same accusations continue to be made against the GPE police despite the fact that the force has been cleared after CARDINAL of the greatest investigations of our time.’
Extended accusations
‘ But PERSON has no confidence in [ prosecutor ] ORG competence and desire to have the whole matter investigated?’

‘ The fact that Professor PERSON now calls into question the work carried out by PERSON and instituted by the Attorney - General [ ORG ] is in itself serious and remarkable . Now the charges have been extended to include superior police authorities as well.’
According to ORG sources , PERSON will very soon contact the Prosecutor - General to hear what the latter intends to do about PERSON extended insinuations .

As regards the fact that ORG is being brought into [ the matter ] , Mr PERSON ... affirms that this is as a result of the organisation ’s wish to gain full insight into the situation in the GPE police force . ”

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the first applicant gave a speech as Chairman of ORG at its DATE general assembly , from which PERSON quoted in an article dated DATE carrying the headline “ PERSON accused of defamation ” . The article read , inter alia , as follows :

“ ... ORG is serious about its threat to bring defamation proceedings against Professor PERSON . According to PERSON , Chairman of the ORG , a summons against PERSON will be issued within DATE requesting that CARDINAL specific written statements he has made in connection with the police brutality case in GPE be declared null and void .
Refused

‘ Professor PERSON has had an opportunity to apologise for the CARDINAL specific points which we find to be defamatory of the police as a professional group , but he has refused . Therefore we are instituting proceedings . No compensation will be claimed ; we are merely seeking to have the statements declared null and void.’
Critical eyes

PERSON also mentioned this matter in his opening speech to the national assembly and said , among other things , that society ’s power structure had to tolerate critical eyes . However , this presupposed a responsible and reliable attitude on the part of the critics . He strongly denounced unobjective debates on police brutality fostered by powerful forces of high social status .
Dilettantes

‘ PERSON status as a professor has lent credibility to the allegations of police brutality , and this has undermined the respect for and confidence in the police . ORG will not accept the appointment of a new commission to investigate allegations of police brutality ; nor will it accept private investigations on a grand scale made by dilettantes and intended to fabricate allegations of police brutality which are then made public’ , said PERSON .
Verbal attacks
Mr PERSON described verbal attacks on the police as an attempt to undermine the dignity and authority of the police . ”

CARDINAL . In a special edition of the law journal LOC , published in DATE , the police and the prosecution authorities presented their views on the investigation ordered by ORG and the ensuing investigation into the suspected false statements given by Mr ORG informers .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG and its GPE branch brought defamation proceedings against PERSON , seeking to have his above - cited statements in “ Documentation of police brutality and other misconduct in the GPE police force ” declared null and void ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . In DATE PERSON , for his part , instituted defamation proceedings against the applicants , requesting that a number of their statements be declared null and void .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , in view of ORG Rights’ PERSON GPE v. GPE judgment of DATE ( Series A no . CARDINAL ) , the associations withdrew their defamation action against Mr Bratholm . The latter refused to withdraw his case against the applicants .

CARDINAL . The Oslo City Court heard the case against the applicants from CARDINAL DATE to CARDINAL DATE , during which evidence was taken from CARDINAL witnesses and extensive documentary evidence was submitted .

In its judgment of DATE ORG observed , inter alia , that it was established that unlawful use of violence had occurred in GPE and that , although it had emanated from very few police officers , the extent of the violence was problematic . PERSON had not assailed his GPE integrity and had not expressed himself in a manner that could justify the ORG attack on him . It found the following statements defamatory under LAW and declared them null and void ( død og maktesløs , mortifisert ) under LAW ( the numbering below follows that appearing in the national courts’ judgments ) :
( Statements by the second applicant published by ORG on CARDINAL DATE )
CARDINAL NORP “ He describes Professor PERSON ’s recent report on police brutality in the GPE police force as ‘ pure misinformation intended to harm the police’ . ”
CARDINAL NORP “ Until the contrary has been proved I would characterise this as a deliberate lie . ”
NORP “ There must be other ulterior motives . It appears as if the purpose has been to undermine confidence in the police . ”
( Statements by the first applicant published by ORG and DATE respectively )
CARDINAL “ In my view , CARDINAL is faced with a form of skulduggery and private investigation where there is good reason to question the honesty of the motives . ”
CARDINAL NORP “ ORG will not accept ... private investigations on a grand scale made by dilettantes and intended to fabricate allegations of police brutality which are then made public . ”
On the other hand , ORG rejected PERSON claims with respect to the following statements by the first applicant published by PERSON on DATE and DATE :

CARDINAL NORP “ I am puzzled by the motives behind such allegations . At any rate , it can not be in the interests of the rule of law and the public good to create such problems for an entire service . ”
CARDINAL NORP “ Mr PERSON described verbal attacks on the police as an attempt to undermine the dignity and authority of the police . ”

ORG ordered the first applicant to pay MONEY ( ORG ) for non - pecuniary damage to PERSON but dismissed the latter ’s claim for non - pecuniary damage against the second applicant on the ground that it had been submitted out of time . ORG further ordered that the applicants pay PERSON respectively ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL and ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL for legal costs .
ORG judgment included the following reasons :

“ Statement CARDINAL ... is an unequivocal allegation that PERSON book contains false allegations of police violence within the GPE police . The expression ‘ misinformation’ may be understood as being a neutral assertion that PERSON provides false information , or to mean that he should be aware that he [ does so ] , or that he [ does it ] deliberately . The ORG emphasises that the phrase ‘ pure misinformation intended to harm the police’ must be read in connection with the rest of the text – particularly statement CARDINAL and the last paragraph of the interview – and has come to the conclusion that an ordinary reader would understand the statement as follows :
‘ With the intent of harming the police , PERSON is deliberately imparting false information on police brutality.’

The ORG has no doubt that this is an assertion that constitutes a defamatory allegation . It is both offensive to PERSON sense of honour and liable to harm his reputation . The allegation is not a subjective characterisation , but an assertion about a matter of fact that can be proved by means of evidence . The accusation can thus be declared null and void .

The ORG would add that , when read in context , the statement can not be construed as an accusation that PERSON himself is making false allegations of police brutality . However , even if the statement must be understood to be an allegation against persons other than PERSON ( of making false accusations of police brutality ) , this does not alter its character as an allegation aimed at PERSON . When read in its entirety , the text clearly indicates that it is PERSON book which PERSON is referring to .
When statement [ CARDINAL ] is read in the context of the rest of the text , which essentially deals with PERSON book , an ordinary reader would understand it as follows :
‘ PERSON is deliberately passing on assertions about police brutality which he knows are lies.’

Whether statement DATE can be interpreted in such a way that it also targets the informers is of no significance here either . Nor does the ORG doubt that this statement constitutes a defamatory allegation directed at PERSON which may be declared null and void because its truth can be tested by evidence .

[ Statement CARDINAL.CARDINAL ] must be understood as a clear assertion that PERSON purpose ( in writing the book PERSON ) has been to undermine confidence in the police . When read in the context of the rest of the text , especially statements CARDINAL.CARDINAL and CARDINAL , it must be understood as an assertion that PERSON for this purpose is passing on allegations of police brutality which he knows to be untrue . The statement also includes an implicit denigration of PERSON purpose as questionable and unworthy . ‘ Other motives’ answers the question whether PERSON motives can be doubted , i.e. as opposed to honourable motives such as , for instance , to promote the rule of law .

The ORG has no doubt that the assertion is an allegation which has both offended PERSON sense of honour and is liable to harm his reputation . The part of the assertion alleging that PERSON intention is to undermine the police can be proved to be true or false . That PERSON intention , with the statement worded as it is , must be understood by the reader as questionable or reprehensible is a subjective value judgment that can hardly be proved true or false . However , this does not in principle mean that statement CARDINAL may not be declared null and void .

[ Statement CARDINAL ] is not unequivocal as to whom it is directed against . It can be understood as being directed against PERSON ( probably also against others ) , when seen in the light of the CARDINAL preceding passages stating that PERSON ( together with PERSON and Mr Nordhus ) is trying a new move and that PERSON ( amongst others ) is transgressing the limits of neutral research . When read in its context , the statement may also be understood to imply that it is not at all directed against PERSON , but against ORG . Such an interpretation must be based on the fact that the newspaper interviewed PERSON just because ORG had become involved in the matter . As a third possibility , the ORG mentions that the statement DATE especially when read in the context of the caption in the newspaper DATE may be understood by an ordinary reader to imply that it is first of all directed at Mr PERSON and Mr GPE , but also at PERSON .

The ORG has reached the conclusion that when read in context statement [ CARDINAL ] must be interpreted in any event as an assertion that PERSON , among others , has questionable motives for his involvement , and that PERSON is engaged in and/or contributes to what PERSON describes as skulduggery and private investigation , not impartial research .

The statement in part includes value judgments ( ‘ ORG , ‘ private investigation’ ) , which are not liable to be declared null and void . However , the statement also includes an assertion on matters of fact , i.e. that there are dishonest motives and that PERSON is not neutral .

The statement must obviously be understood to be an assertion that it is Mr Bratholm whose motives are dishonest . This follows from the first and second paragraphs preceding the statement , where PERSON first mentions that PERSON ( together with Mr GPE and Mr PERSON ) is trying a new move , and then claims that PERSON , among others , has exceeded the limits of impartial research .

The ORG has no doubt that this assertion constitutes a defamatory allegation against PERSON . It is both offensive to his sense of honour and liable to harm his reputation . The truth of the allegation can be tested by evidence and it may therefore be declared null and void .

Statement CARDINAL contains an assertion that allegations of police brutality are being fabricated and then made public . When read in connection with the rest of the text , this must be interpreted by an ordinary reader as an assertion that Mr Bratholm publicises false allegations of police brutality . This assertion can be proved to be true or false , and is in principle liable to be declared null and void .

The statement does not include only the said assertion . When the assertion is also understood to mean that PERSON is publicising allegations that he should have realised are false it follows that it is also offensive to PERSON sense of honour and liable to harm his reputation . The assertion implies that he , as an expert , is heedlessly publicising false allegations of police brutality . However , when read in context the statement can not be understood solely in this way .
The statement must be interpreted as an assertion that PERSON is taking part in a private investigation for the purpose of fabricating allegations of police brutality .

If the assertion is to be interpreted as also being directed at persons other than Mr Bratholm , this does not preclude its being directed at him . Accordingly , statement CARDINAL must also be interpreted as a defamatory allegation against PERSON , the truth of which can be tested by evidence . ”

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed against ORG judgment to ORG ( PERSON ) , challenging the former court ’s interpretation of their statements . Without any support in their wording or the context , it had interpreted the statements as calling into question PERSON honesty and motives . In no event could the statements be regarded as unlawful , as they had been expressed in response to his damaging value judgments of the profession . The applicants invoked , inter alia , LAW pursuant to which a court could refrain from imposing a penalty if the injured party had provoked the defendant or retaliated in a reprehensible manner . A crucial factor was that PERSON attacks on the associations which the applicants represented constituted such provocation and retaliation .

In his cross - appeal PERSON challenged ORG findings with respect to statements CARDINAL and CARDINAL . Moreover , he emphasised , inter alia , that he had not questioned the honesty of the applicants or any other officials . His criticism had been directed against a system and enjoyed special protection under LAW .
On DATE ORG ( kjæremålsutvalget ) of ORG granted leave to appeal on points of law .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected both appeals , thereby upholding ORG judgment , and ordered each of the applicants to pay ORG CARDINAL in additional costs to PERSON .
On behalf of the court , PERSON Justice PERSON stated , inter alia :

“ In the present case the interest in freedom of expression carries particular weight . The statements sought to be declared null and void were made in a public debate concerning police brutality . Police brutality – and by this I mean the use of illegal physical force by the police against individuals – is a matter of serious public concern . It is of central importance for democracy that a debate concerning such matters may take place as far as possible without a risk of sanctions being imposed on those who participate . It is of particular importance to allow a wide leeway for criticism in matters of public concern ( see LAW ) . However , those who act in defence against the criticism , for instance the representatives of the GPE police , should of course also enjoy this freedom of expression .

However , freedom of expression does not go as far as [ allowing ] every statement in a debate , even if the debate relates to matters of public concern . Freedom of expression must be weighed against the rights of the injured party . The limit between statements which may be permissible and statements which may be declared null and void must in principle be set at statements which relate to the other person ’s personal honesty or motives ...

Nor do accusations of lies , improper motives , dishonesty ... serve to promote freedom of expression but , perhaps , rather to suppress or prevent a debate which should have been allowed to take place .

[ The applicants’ ] argument that the [ impugned ] statements can not be declared null and void because they include subjective value judgments which are not susceptible of proof , is in my view untenable . The statements include , among other things , accusations of deliberate lies , unworthy motives and intent to damage the police . The truth of this type of statement can in principle be proved . The fact that [ the applicants ] have made no attempt to present such proof is another matter .

In the assessment of whether the [ statements ] are to be considered unlawful [ rettsstridig ] the aggrieved party ’s own conduct may also be relevant . A person who uses strong language may have to tolerate more than others . I will revert to Mr ORG conduct . Suffice it to say , in this context , that I can not see that his strong involvement [ in the debate ] can be decisive with respect to those statements which clearly question whether he is lying or has acceptable motives .

[ The applicants ] have submitted that , regardless of whether the statements are unlawful , the request for a null and void order must be refused , in accordance with an application by analogy of LAW . To this I would ... say that [ this ] provision scarcely has any independent significance any longer – at least as regards provocation . In the case - law , the injured party ’s own conduct has become more central in the determination of [ whether a statement should be considered unlawful ] and in violation of LAW . I fail to see that there can be any room for exemption from penalty if the statement is unlawful . This approach would be the same if LAW ... had also been applicable to nullification . For this reason alone , there are no grounds for application by analogy , as pleaded by [ the applicants ] .
I should think that the reasoning I have ... presented is also correct in respect of retaliation . In any event there [ was in the present case ] no retaliation such as that required ...

I agree with ORG that [ the statements in question ] fall under LAW . Read in their context , they are directed against PERSON . In statement PERSON he is accused of deliberate lies . An accusation of falsehood is also implied in statement CARDINAL by the word ‘ PERSON . [ Statement ] CARDINAL implies unworthy motives and suggests malicious intent [ underlying PERSON attacks against the police ] . This is also implied in statement CARDINAL . The defamatory nature of the [ second applicant ’s ] statements becomes clearer and is thus reinforced when the statements are read together .
The interest in freedom of expression can not make these statements lawful . I refer to what I have said about statements which are directed against personal honesty and integrity .

It has been submitted that PERSON own situation must be of central importance in the evaluation of the issue of lawfulness . He has , it is being alleged , made strong and derogatory statements against his opponents in the debate and must accept that an embarrassing light is put on him as well .
I agree that PERSON voices harsh criticism in his book ‘ Police Brutality’ . A lot of this criticism is against a system , but a lot of it is also directed against persons .

PERSON uses a number of derogatory expressions . ‘ Misinformation’ has been singled out as CARDINAL of them . I can not see , for instance , that the use of that expression carries any significant weight when the lawfulness of the impugned statements is being assessed . PERSON point in using this expression has been , inter alia , to expose a deliberate or negligent denial of the existence of police brutality . Such denial is a prerequisite for the occurrence of police brutality on an appreciable scale .

The word despotism has also been mentioned . In the manner it is used in the preface to PERSON book it is not linked to the GPE police force ... The fact that the use of words such as ‘ despotism’ probably contributed to raising the temperature and the general noise level of the debate may be relevant to the assessment of the lawfulness [ of the impugned statements ] . Having regard to the entire context , however , I can not see that PERSON choice of words or manner of presentation of his views either in ‘ Police Brutality’ or in connection with the commercialisation of the book can justify calling into question his integrity as was done in the statements under consideration .

It is noted that the appellants have forcefully submitted that their statements were made in their capacity as representatives of the police and that , as such , they must enjoy a particular protection against their statements being declared null and void . I agree that it was natural for PERSON and PERSON as representatives to look after the interests of the police officers in the debate . As I have already mentioned , their freedom of expression should be protected to the same extent as the freedom of those who direct the attention towards possible questionable circumstances within the police force . But , as already pointed out , there is a limit also in respect of them . That limit has been overstepped in this case .
Accordingly , I conclude along with ORG that statements CARDINAL , CARDINAL must be declared null and void .
I will now turn to PERSON statements ...
[ Statement CARDINAL ] ... directly assails the honesty of PERSON motives . That this is what is being questioned is reinforced when the statement is read in the context of the whole article ...
I therefore agree with ORG that statement CARDINAL must be declared null and void ...

Statement CARDINAL is tantamount to an assertion that allegations of police brutality are being fabricated and then made public . The basis for my doubts is as follows :

[ Mr Justice PERSON ] pointed out that in a public debate on ‘ matters of public concern’ ... the threshold for what the participants may state without being found liable for defamation should be very high . Even if this is accepted , I agree that it should not legitimise attacks directed against the opponent ’s personal integrity , or which devalue or throw suspicion on his motives for participating in the debate .

For my part , I find it hard to see how the statements which ORG ... declared null and void could be said to have been particularly directed against Mr Bratholm as a private individual . But I shall leave that aside , since I consider that in a heated public debate attacking another person ’s integrity and motives instead of what the person has stated must be deemed unlawful as such .

What in particular causes a problem for me is that – as I see it – it was PERSON himself who had called into question the integrity of the police , in particular that of ORG , when the debate on police brutality resumed in DATE . In LAW of [ the book ] he states the following about the concept ‘ misinformation’ :

‘ “ Misinformation ” can be defined in various ways . CARDINAL possible definition is untrue information , irrespective of whether the information is provided in good faith . It may , for example , be discovered subsequently that the research was mistaken on some point .

There is little reason to place such a wide construction on the concept of misinformation . It is more practical to understand it as meaning deliberate or negligent dissemination of incorrect information . Misinformation in this sense is a problem that is easier to deal with than when our understanding is broadened only gradually .

If I were to base my conclusion on scattered information and impressions , it would be that the misinformation has been rather successful . I can not read this in any other way than that PERSON here indeed himself accuses his opponents in the debate – ‘ the police , its organisations and LAW – of lack of integrity , of knowingly hiding factual circumstances and of acting on the basis of inappropriate motives .

It is in my view on this basis that the appellants’ statements must be evaluated DATE and in particular those which were made after the publication of ‘ Police Brutality’ in DATE . The appellants’ submission that they , who naturally must have felt offended on behalf of the police , were entitled to reply in the same manner is not as such ill - founded .

In this connection it is in my view also of importance that the appellants expressed themselves on behalf of the police organisations in GPE and at the national level , respectively . They acted as elected representatives and spokesmen of the members . Very likely , and rightly so , they considered it an organisational duty to react to the attacks which were directed against the working methods of the police . It is not unusual in our society for the representatives of a profession to reply to public attacks in a way which might be lacking the necessary reflection and which might be somewhat inappropriate . The appellants were not familiar with the legislation on defamation either .

PERSON has maintained that there must be a difference between what wellknown politicians must endure in respect of statements related to their political activities and the protection he enjoys when ‘ from his professional standpoint he engages in important matters of public ORG . CARDINAL . Under LAW , a defamatory statement which is unlawful and has not been proved may be declared null and void by a court . The relevant part of this provision reads :

“ CARDINAL . When evidence of the truth of an allegation is admissible and such evidence has not been produced , the aggrieved person may demand that the allegation be declared null and void unless otherwise provided by statute . ”
Such a declaration is applicable only with regard to factual statements , the truth of value judgments not being susceptible of proof .

Although the provisions on orders declaring a statement null and void are contained in LAW , such an order is not considered a criminal sanction but a judicial finding that the defendant has failed to prove its truth and is thus viewed as a civil - law remedy .

In DATE there has been a debate in GPE as to whether one should abolish the remedy of null and void orders , which has existed in NORP law since DATE and which may also be found in the laws of GPE and GPE . Because of its being deemed a particularly lenient form of sanction , ORG has expressed a wish to maintain it .

He may also be ordered to pay such compensation for non - pecuniary damage as the court deems reasonable .
